Question 87) Diabetes insipidus complain about the confusion made by health professionals regarding both types of diabetes: mellitus and insipidus. While the first type is associated with insulin levels or action, the second is not linked to the deficiency of this hormone. Diabetes insipidus is characterized by a disorder in the production or functioning of the antidiuretic hormone (in the acronym in English, ADH), secreted by the neurohypophin to control water reabsorption by the renal tubules.
Given the functional role of ADH, what is a classic symptom of a patient affected by diabetes insipidus?
A) High blood glucose rate.
B) Increased blood pressure.
C) body mass gain.
D) chronic anemia.
E) dehydration.
